description: From Middle English dydoppar, from earlier douedoppe, deuedep, dyuedap with agentive suffix -er, from Old English dūfedoppa (“diving bird, pelican”), from dūfan (“to dive”) + *doppa (“diver”) (whence modern English dop (“diving bird”)). Synchronically equivalent to dive +‎ dop +‎ -er.

entries.meaning: A small diving water bird frequenting rivers and fresh waters, specifically a little grebe or dabchick.
examples: The misery of man may fitly be compar'd to a Di­dapper, who when she is under water, past our sight, and indeed can seem no more to us, rises again;  […]

entries.meaning: (obsolete, derogatory) A scoundrel, a worthless person
examples: If a Martin can play at cheſtes, as well as his nephewe the ape, he ſhall knowe what it is for a ſcaddle pawne, to croſſe a Biſhop in his owne walke. Such dydoppers must be taken vp, els theile not ſtick to check the king.
